title: 103_s1224
content:
- This Act may be cited as the Multiethnic Placement Act of 1993.
- Findings and Purpose. Findings from Congress reveal that nearly 500,000 children are in foster care in the United States, with tens of thousands waiting for adoption. The median length of time for children waiting to be adopted is two years and eight months. The purpose of this Act is to decrease the length of time for children waiting to be adopted and prevent discrimination in the placement of children based on ethnicity. Placement of children on the basis of race, color, or national origin. -S-E-C-. -3-. -M-U-L-T-I-E-T-H-N-I-C -P-L-A-C-E-M-E-N-T-S-. - Prohibition: An agency receiving federal assistance involved in adoption or foster care placements may not delay or deny placement of a child based on race, color, or national origin of the adoptive or foster parent or the child. Permissible consideration: An agency may consider other factors. In adoption or foster care placements, agencies must not base placement decisions on race, color, or national origin of the child or parents. Other relevant factors may be considered in the best interests of the child. The term "placement decision" refers to the decision to place, delay, or deny a child in foster care. In adoption or foster care placements, the decision involves seeking termination of birth parent rights or making a child legally available for adoptive placement. The Secretary of Health and Human Services cannot provide adoption assistance funds to non-compliant agencies. Equitable relief can be sought for any violations. Subsection (a) allows individuals aggrieved by agency violations to seek relief in a United States District Court. This section does not affect adoption or foster care placements under the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. The Act is titled the "Multiethnic Placement Act of 1993" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purpose. The "Multiethnic Placement Act of 1993" aims to reduce adoption waiting times for children in foster care and prevent discrimination based on race, color, or national origin in placement procedures. Congress recognizes the high number of children in foster care, the need for more adoptive parents from diverse backgrounds, and the importance of eliminating discrimination in adoption and foster care recruitment. The "Multiethnic Placement Act of 1993" addresses multiethnic placements in adoption and foster care to prevent discrimination based on race, color, or national origin. The "Multiethnic Placement Act of 1993" prohibits agencies from denying adoption or foster care based on race, color, or national origin, and from discriminating in placement decisions on these grounds. Agencies may consider these factors in placement decisions. The "Multiethnic Placement Act of 1993" allows agencies to consider race, color, or national origin in placement decisions if relevant to the child's best interests. The term "placement decision" includes placing a child in foster care or adoptive home, seeking termination of birth parent rights, or making a child legally available for adoption. The Secretary of Health and Human Services cannot provide funds to agencies that discriminate based on race, color, or national origin. The Social Security Act prohibits agencies from non-compliance with certain subsections. Individuals aggrieved by such actions have the right to seek relief in a US district court. This section does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978.
